summary: This is a legal memorandum filed by Jeffrey Epstein's defense attorney, Reid Weingarten, to Judge Richard M. Berman. It argues for Epstein's pretrial release on bail, proposing stringent conditions and challenging the government's claims of flight risk and danger. The document references Epstein's 2007 Non-Prosecution Agreement (NPA) and his 2008 state guilty plea. This is a defense motion filed in the Southern District of New York (Case 1:19-cr-00490) arguing for Jeffrey Epstein's pretrial release. The document challenges the government's bail position, asserts that the 2008 Non-Prosecution Agreement (NPA) should bar the current prosecution, raises issues of pre-indictment delay and prosecutorial misconduct, and proposes extensive conditions for release including home confinement with private security. This document is part of a 2019 court filing (Document 6) in the case against Jeffrey Epstein. It includes a legal argument for his pretrial release based on the Sixth Amendment, followed by the full text of the 2007 Non-Prosecution Agreement (NPA) and its Addendum. The NPA details the agreement between Epstein and the U.S. Attorney's Office to resolve federal charges in exchange for a state plea deal and includes provisions for victims and immunity for named associates. This is a sealed motion filed by the United States (the government) in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of Florida, seeking to dismiss a petition by Jane Doe #1 and Jane Doe #2 under the Crime Victims' Rights Act (CVRA). The government argues the court lacks subject matter jurisdiction because the petitioners lack Article III standing and their claims are not constitutionally ripe. The core dispute centers on the petitioners' desire to invalidate a non-prosecution agreement between Jeffrey Epstein and the U.S. Attorney's Office to enable consultation about potential federal charges. This document is a legal filing by the United States Attorney's Office for the Southern District of Florida, arguing for the dismissal of petitions filed by victims (Petitioners) under the Crime Victims' Rights Act (CVRA). It contends the victims' claims are premature and constitutionally unripe, as the Non-Prosecution Agreement with Jeffrey Epstein does not preclude federal charges in other districts, and the victims remain free to confer with prosecutors elsewhere.

events.title: Non-Prosecution Agreement (NPA) Signed
events.description: The Department of Justice, through the U.S. Attorney for the Southern District of Florida, entered into a Non-Prosecution Agreement (NPA) with Jeffrey Epstein, immunizing him from five potential federal charges, including 18 U.S.C. § 1591 (sex trafficking).

events.title: State Guilty Plea and Sentencing
events.description: As required by the 2007 NPA, Jeffrey Epstein entered a state-court guilty plea for conduct overlapping the current indictment. He received a 30-month sentence (18 months incarceration, 12 months probation with home confinement) and was required to register as a sex offender.

events.title: Arrest and Indictment in SDNY
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was arrested and indicted in the Southern District of New York (Case 1:19-cr-00490) on sex trafficking charges related to alleged conduct from 2002-2005.

events.title: Government Filing in CVRA Litigation
events.description: A filing by the government in the Southern District of Florida CVRA litigation (Jane Doe #1 and Jane Doe #2 v. United States) was unsealed. It stated Epstein was subject to potential prosecution in other districts like SDNY and invited alleged victims to contact those offices.

events.title: Epstein's Florida Guilty Plea
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein pleaded guilty to state felony charges (violating Fla. Stat. §§ 796.07 and 796.03) as part of a Non-Prosecution Agreement (NPA), requiring him to register as a sex offender.

events.title: New York Federal Indictment and Arrest
events.description: Epstein was arrested and indicted in the Southern District of New York on federal sex trafficking charges (conspiracy and substantive counts).

events.title: Alleged Conduct Period
events.description: The period during which the conduct immunized by the 2008 NPA allegedly occurred, and which is also referenced in the 2019 New York indictment.

events.title: CVRA Litigation in Southern District of Florida
events.description: Ongoing litigation under the Crime Victims' Rights Act where a violation was found regarding victim notification related to the 2008 NPA. The defense claims the USAO-SDFL later encouraged victims to seek prosecution in other districts.

events.title: Signing of Non-Prosecution Agreement
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein signs a Non-Prosecution Agreement with the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of Florida to resolve federal charges related to sex trafficking of minors in exchange for a state plea deal.

events.title: Deadline for Guilty Plea and Sentencing
events.description: Per the NPA, Epstein was to use his best efforts to enter his guilty plea and be sentenced in state court by this date.

events.title: Self-Reporting Deadline for Jail
events.description: The NPA states the U.S. had no objection to Epstein self-reporting to begin serving his state jail sentence by this date.

events.title: Addendum to NPA Signed
events.description: An addendum to the Non-Prosecution Agreement is signed, clarifying the process for selecting and paying an attorney representative for victims.

events.title: Filing of Motion for Pretrial Release
events.description: Epstein's defense attorneys file a motion in his 2019 federal case arguing for his pretrial release based on Sixth Amendment grounds and his conduct over the past 14 years.

events.title: Hearing on Petition
events.description: A court hearing was held regarding the petitioners' CVRA claims, where they acknowledged the non-prosecution agreement induced Epstein's guilty plea and they sought its invalidation.

events.title: Meeting with U.S. Attorney
events.description: The U.S. Attorney for the Southern District of Florida, along with prosecutors, personally conferred with petitioners' counsel and Jane Doe #1 about their desire to see Epstein federally prosecuted.

events.title: Signing of Non-Prosecution Agreement
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein and the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of Florida entered into a non-prosecution agreement, deferring federal prosecution in favor of state prosecution.

events.title: Recusal of USAO-SDFL
events.description: The U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of Florida was recused by the DOJ from the Epstein investigation, with responsibility reassigned to the Middle District of Florida.

events.title: Hearing on Victim Petitions
events.description: A court hearing referenced in the transcript where Petitioners acknowledged the best relief they could hope for was the right to confer with government attorneys.

keyFacts: The defense argues the current SDNY indictment is barred by a 2007 federal Non-Prosecution Agreement (NPA) that promised Epstein immunity and a 'global settlement' for offenses including those under 18 U.S.C. § 1591.

Epstein's defense proposes an extensive set of 14 bail conditions, including home detention in his $77M Manhattan residence, GPS monitoring, surrendering his passport, grounding his private jet, and having his brother and a friend serve as co-sureties.

The memorandum emphasizes Epstein's 14-year record without alleged criminal recurrence (2005-2019) and his 10-year 'scrupulous' compliance with sex offender registration requirements across multiple jurisdictions as proof he is not a danger or flight risk.

The defense contests the characterization of the case as 'Sex Trafficking,' arguing the indictment alleges no commercial profit, force, coercion, fraud, or enslavement, and that the conduct is 'purely local' and falls within classic state sex offenses.

The document reveals that in 2013, the government itself stated in court filings that Epstein was subject to potential prosecution in other districts like SDNY, yet Epstein did not flee in the six years between that notice and his 2019 arrest.
The defense argues the 2008 Non-Prosecution Agreement (NPA) provided 'global' immunity for federal crimes related to the 2001-2007 conduct and should bar the 2019 New York prosecution.

The defense alleges prosecutorial misconduct, claiming that after Epstein complied with the NPA, the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of Florida encouraged alleged victims to pursue prosecution in other districts.

Epstein's defense proposes an extensive set of release conditions including GPS monitoring, surrender of passport, grounding of his private plane, a substantial bond secured by his properties, and 24-hour private armed guards at his New York home.

The motion raises a legal defense to the sex trafficking statute (18 U.S.C. § 1591), arguing it targets providers/pimps, not purchasers/johns, and thus Epstein's alleged conduct as a purchaser falls outside its scope.
The defense highlights Epstein's decade of compliance with sex offender registration requirements (in Florida, New York, and the U.S. Virgin Islands) as evidence he is not a flight risk or danger.

The 2007 Non-Prosecution Agreement granted Epstein and named potential co-conspirators (Sarah Kellen, Adriana Ross, Lesley Groff, Nadia Mareinkova) immunity from federal prosecution in exchange for Epstein's state guilty plea.
The agreement required Epstein to plead guilty to state charges of solicitation of prostitution and solicitation of minors, serve 18 months in county jail, and 12 months of community control.
The agreement contained provisions for victim compensation under 18 U.S.C. § 2255, with Epstein agreeing to pay for an attorney representative for identified victims.
The NPA was signed by U.S. Attorney R. Alexander Acosta, signaling high-level DOJ approval of the deal.
In 2019, Epstein's new defense team cited this 14-year-old agreement and his conduct since then as part of their argument for his pretrial release in the new federal case.

The U.S. government is seeking dismissal of a CVRA petition filed by two alleged victims (Jane Doe #1 and #2) for lack of subject matter jurisdiction, arguing they lack standing and their claims are not ripe.
The petitioners seek to invalidate a non-prosecution agreement between Jeffrey Epstein and the U.S. Attorney's Office to enable consultation about potential federal charges against him.

The government argues that even if the agreement were set aside, due process requires it to adhere to the agreement's terms because Epstein, a contracting party, is not a party to the CVRA proceedings.

The government contends the non-prosecution agreement does not bar federal prosecution of Epstein in other districts (e.g., SDNY, New Jersey) and that petitioners have had and continue to have opportunities to confer with prosecutors.
The document reveals the USAO-SDFL has been recused from the Epstein matter, with responsibility transferred to the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Middle District of Florida.

The U.S. Attorney's Office argues the 2008 Non-Prosecution Agreement with Jeffrey Epstein does not bar federal prosecution in any district other than the Southern District of Florida, nor for offenses not identified in the agreement.

The government contends that petitions by victims under the Crime Victims' Rights Act (CVRA) are premature and constitutionally unripe, as victims can still confer with U.S. Attorney's Offices in other districts about potential charges.

The filing cites the United States Attorney's Manual, stating no district can make an agreement binding another district without written approval from the affected U.S. Attorney(s) or the Assistant Attorney General.

The legal argument centers on subject matter jurisdiction, claiming the court should dismiss the victims' claims because they are based on hypothetical future events (being denied the right to confer).
